pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 206, 365, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 312, 386, 327]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 356]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 371]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 890, 400]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 382, 414]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 890, 458]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 890, 473]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 555, 503]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 764, 532]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 533, 465, 547]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 548, 359, 562]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 562, 628, 577]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0kg\) to be \(10N\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10m / s^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of a micrometer screw gauge.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 98, 650, 209]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 830, 240]]<|/det|>
What is the smallest reading that can be achieved using this micrometer screw gauge?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 250, 150, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 250, 250, 268]]<|/det|>
0.0001 mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 250, 395, 268]]<|/det|>
B 0.01 mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 250, 550, 268]]<|/det|>
C 0.1 mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 250, 700, 268]]<|/det|>
D 1 mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 295, 96, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 295, 593, 313]]<|/det|>
A small, light ball is dropped from the top of a tall building.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 325, 655, 343]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows how the speed of the ball changes with time?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[208, 352, 787, 723]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 753, 94, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 753, 918, 785]]<|/det|>
A runner runs \(300 \text{m}\) at an average speed of \(3.0 \text{m/s}\). She then runs another \(300 \text{m}\) at an average speed of \(6.0 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 798, 598, 815]]<|/det|>
What is her average speed for the total distance of \(600 \text{m}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 826, 720, 844]]<|/det|>
A 2.0m/s B 4.0m/s C 4.5m/s D 8.0m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A helium balloon is tied to a top-pan balance. A metal block of mass \(100\mathrm{g}\) is placed on the balance. The reading on the balance is \(91\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[300, 112, 695, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 357, 578, 374]]<|/det|>
Which statement can be deduced from this experiment?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 386, 735, 403]]<|/det|>
A The balloon exerts a downward force of 0.09 N on the top-pan balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 411, 428]]<|/det|>
B The helium has a mass of \(-9g\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 437, 411, 453]]<|/det|>
C The helium has a mass of \(+9g\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 673, 478]]<|/det|>
D The resultant downward force on the top-pan balance is 0.91 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 508, 96, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 507, 591, 524]]<|/det|>
A liquid has a volume of \(0.040\mathrm{m}^3\) and a mass of \(30 000\mathrm{g}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 537, 388, 554]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 752, 583]]<|/det|>
A \(0.075kg / m^3\) B \(7.5kg / m^3\) C \(750kg / m^3\) D \(7500kg / m^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 610, 96, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 610, 737, 628]]<|/det|>
A resultant force of 4.0N acts on an object of mass 0.50kg for 3.0 seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 545, 657]]<|/det|>
What is the change in velocity caused by this force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 715, 685]]<|/det|>
A \(4.0m / s\) B \(6.0m / s\) C \(12m / s\) D \(24m / s\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 714, 94, 732]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 404, 731]]<|/det|>
Which quantities are both vectors?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 743, 339, 758]]<|/det|>
A acceleration and force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 369, 784]]<|/det|>
B acceleration and pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 795, 297, 810]]<|/det|>
C density and force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 820, 328, 835]]<|/det|>
D density and pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 724, 90]]<|/det|>
A moving ball with a momentum of \(25 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) collides head-on with a wall.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 102, 654, 205]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 219, 919, 252]]<|/det|>
It rebounds from the wall with the same speed but in the opposite direction. The time of collision is \(50 \text{ms}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 263, 750, 280]]<|/det|>
What is the average force exerted on the wall by the ball during the collision?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 291, 715, 308]]<|/det|>
A 0.50N B 1.00N C 500N D 1000N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 338, 94, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 337, 719, 354]]<|/det|>
Which device is designed to convert chemical energy into kinetic energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 300, 381]]<|/det|>
A an a.c. generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 352, 407]]<|/det|>
B a battery-powered torch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 259, 433]]<|/det|>
C a car engine

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 383, 459]]<|/det|>
D a wind-up mechanical clock

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 488, 107, 505]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 488, 919, 520]]<|/det|>
An object, initially at rest, is dropped from a height of \(12.0 \text{m}\). The change in gravitational potential energy when it falls to the ground is \(565 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 402, 549]]<|/det|>
The frictional forces are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 562, 463, 578]]<|/det|>
What is its speed when it hits the ground?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 725, 606]]<|/det|>
A 4.71m/s B 15.5m/s C 47.1m/s D 240m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 636, 107, 654]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 636, 308, 653]]<|/det|>
A man climbs a ladder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 666, 737, 682]]<|/det|>
Which two quantities can be used to calculate the useful power of the man?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 694, 531, 710]]<|/det|>
A the weight of the man and the time taken only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 720, 638, 736]]<|/det|>
B the weight of the man and the vertical distance moved only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 747, 566, 763]]<|/det|>
C the work done by the man and the time taken only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 773, 673, 789]]<|/det|>
D the work done by the man and the vertical distance moved only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 635, 90]]<|/det|>
A manometer is used to measure the pressure of a gas supply.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 100, 715, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 268, 520, 285]]<|/det|>
Which change gives a greater value of height \(h?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 365, 390]]<|/det|>
A using a less dense liquid B using a more dense liquid C using a narrower tube D using a wider tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 418, 107, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 919, 466]]<|/det|>
A washbasin has an exit pipe covered with a plug of area \(12 \text{cm}^2\). A chain is attached to the centre of the plug to assist in pulling the plug away from the exit hole. The washbasin contains water to a depth of \(0.080 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 479, 443, 496]]<|/det|>
The density of the water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 507, 643, 692]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 704, 559, 720]]<|/det|>
What is the force acting on the plug due to the water?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 731, 728, 747]]<|/det|>
A 0.96N B 800N C 9600N D 80000N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 675, 90]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows apparatus being used to observe smoke particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 588, 120]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 shows how a smoke particle moves randomly.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 885, 393]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 490, 423]]<|/det|>
Why do the smoke particles move randomly?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 146, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 435, 397, 452]]<|/det|>
They are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 144, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 462, 395, 478]]<|/det|>
They are less dense than air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 488, 484, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 488, 484, 504]]<|/det|>
They are moved by convection currents.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 514, 416, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 514, 416, 530]]<|/det|>
They gain energy from the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 558, 107, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 692, 575]]<|/det|>
The gas in a sealed container is compressed at constant temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 727, 605]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows how the pressure of the gas changes with its volume?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 615, 764, 914]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The distance between two electricity pylons is \(60 \text{m}\). An engineer fits a cable of length \(62 \text{m}\) between the pylons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 905, 135]]<|/det|>
Why does the engineer choose a cable that is longer than the distance between the two pylons?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 572, 163]]<|/det|>
A to allow for contraction of the cable in cold weather

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 173, 607, 189]]<|/det|>
B to create a slope in the cable for electrons to flow down

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 515, 215]]<|/det|>
C to keep the current low and the voltage high

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 505, 241]]<|/det|>
D to reduce magnetic fields around the cable

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 269, 107, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 269, 530, 286]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 295, 735, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 367, 609, 384]]<|/det|>
Which change increases the sensitivity of the thermometer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 359, 412]]<|/det|>
A a narrower capillary tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 330, 438]]<|/det|>
B a wider capillary tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 393, 464]]<|/det|>
C thicker glass around the bulb

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 474, 395, 490]]<|/det|>
D thinner glass around the bulb

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 520, 107, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
An object of mass \(800 \text{g}\) and specific heat capacity \(250 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\) is heated. It absorbs \(5300 \text{J}\) of energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 564, 529, 580]]<|/det|>
What is the increase in temperature of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 592, 735, 609]]<|/det|>
A \(0.027^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) B \(17^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) C \(27^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) D \(17 000^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 638, 107, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 638, 786, 655]]<|/det|>
On a cold day, a shiny metal rod feels colder to the touch than a black plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 475, 684]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this observation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 696, 770, 713]]<|/det|>
A The metal rod is a better absorber of infra-red radiation than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 723, 675, 739]]<|/det|>
B The metal rod is a better thermal conductor than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 749, 772, 765]]<|/det|>
C The metal rod is a worse absorber of infra-red radiation than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 775, 677, 791]]<|/det|>
D The metal rod is a worse thermal conductor than the plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 586, 90]]<|/det|>
One end of a copper bar is heated to a high temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 103, 919, 135]]<|/det|>
Which mechanism is responsible for the transfer of thermal energy to the other end of the copper bar?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 135, 164]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 146, 480, 163]]<|/det|>
the lattice vibrations of copper ions only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 173, 915, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 170, 915, 187]]<|/det|>
the lattice vibrations of copper ions and the movement of high energy electrons along the bar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 198, 610, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 197, 610, 214]]<|/det|>
the movement of high energy copper ions along the bar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 628, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 223, 628, 240]]<|/det|>
the movement of high energy electrons along the bar only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 269, 107, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 269, 919, 301]]<|/det|>
Plane water waves travel from a shallow region into a deeper region. They travel more quickly in the deeper water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 311, 670, 422]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 439, 618, 456]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the wave pattern in the deeper water?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 466, 922, 583]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 610, 107, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 693, 628]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the image formed by a plane mirror is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 138, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 640, 445, 657]]<|/det|>
The image is larger than the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 666, 457, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 666, 457, 682]]<|/det|>
The image is smaller than the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 692, 148, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 692, 601, 708]]<|/det|>
The image is twice as far from the mirror as the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 321, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 718, 322, 734]]<|/det|>
The image is virtual.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A ray of light is incident on a glass-air surface. The diagrams show the ray of light at different angles of incidence in the glass.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 880, 195]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 208, 454, 225]]<|/det|>
What is the refractive index of the glass?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 236, 141, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 236, 193, 254]]<|/det|>
1.35

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 236, 312, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[325, 236, 360, 254]]<|/det|>
1.44

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 236, 525, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 236, 526, 254]]<|/det|>
1.50

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 236, 693, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 236, 693, 254]]<|/det|>
<label>1.55</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 281, 107, 300]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 281, 920, 313]]<|/det|>
Different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum are used for different purposes. Below are four statements about parts of the spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 325, 762, 343]]<|/det|>
statement 1: Infra-red waves are used in television remote controllers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 352, 918, 369]]<|/det|>
statement 2: Radio waves are used to transmit television pictures from satellites to Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 378, 675, 395]]<|/det|>
statement 3: Ultraviolet waves are used for intruder alarms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 405, 591, 422]]<|/det|>
statement 4: X-rays are used for security checks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 434, 371, 451]]<|/det|>
Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 133, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 462, 218, 480]]<|/det|>
1 and 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 462, 384, 480]]<|/det|>
B 1 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 462, 551, 480]]<|/det|>
C 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 462, 718, 480]]<|/det|>
D 3 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 508, 107, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 507, 784, 525]]<|/det|>
Iron is used for the core of a transformer and steel is used to make a bar magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 537, 593, 555]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains these uses of iron and of steel?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 566, 131, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 566, 680, 583]]<|/det|>
Iron is a magnetic material and steel is a non-magnetic material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 593, 123, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 593, 824, 610]]<|/det|>
Iron is a permanent magnetic material and steel is a temporary magnetic material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 123, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 619, 824, 636]]<|/det|>
Iron is a temporary magnetic material and steel is a permanent magnetic material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 645, 133, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 645, 680, 662]]<|/det|>
Iron is a non-magnetic material and steel is a magnetic material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 875, 90]]<|/det|>
A sheet of ice floats on water. A source of sound S is positioned at the edge of the ice sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 559, 120]]<|/det|>
Four microphones are placed equal distances from S.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 530, 150]]<|/det|>
Which microphone detects the sound from S first?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 161, 700, 396]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 424, 107, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
A bar magnet is placed inside a current-carrying coil. The diagram shows four different experiments.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 890, 803]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 819, 544, 835]]<|/det|>
In which experiments is the magnet demagnetised?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 846, 720, 863]]<|/det|>
A 1 and 2 B 1 and 3 C 2 and 4 D 3 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 540, 90]]<|/det|> The diagrams represent two different electric fields. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 100, 744, 233]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 246, 510, 263]]<|/det|> A single electron is located in each of the fields. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 277, 920, 308]]<|/det|> Which row gives the correct direction of the force on the electron and the field in which there is a larger force on it? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 500, 466]]<|/det|>
direction of the forcelarger force
A↓field 1
B↓field 2
C↑field 1
D↑field 2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 494, 107, 511]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 823, 511]]<|/det|> The resistance of a component in a circuit is found using an ammeter and a voltmeter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 525, 547, 541]]<|/det|> How are the ammeter and the voltmeter connected? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 628, 570]]<|/det|> **A** the voltmeter and ammeter in parallel with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 618, 596]]<|/det|> **B** the voltmeter and ammeter in series with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 606, 898, 622]]<|/det|> **C** the voltmeter in parallel with the component and the ammeter in series with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 632, 898, 648]]<|/det|> **D** the voltmeter in series with the component and the ammeter in parallel with the component <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 676, 107, 694]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 676, 573, 693]]<|/det|> The table gives data for four different electrical devices. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 706, 479, 722]]<|/det|> Which device develops the greatest power? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 736, 666, 860]]<|/det|>
devicevoltagecurrent
Acar headlight12V3.0A
Bcooling fan110V0.40A
Celectric spark generator400kV0.10mA
Dmains lamp240V0.20A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 907, 90]]<|/det|> The circuit diagram shows a fixed resistor R and a thermistor T used in a potential divider circuit. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 100, 590, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 253, 674, 271]]<|/det|> \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{T}}\) are the potential differences across R and T respectively. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 284, 767, 301]]<|/det|> What happens to \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) and to \(V_{\mathrm{T}}\) as the temperature of the thermistor decreases? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 313, 518, 441]]<|/det|>
\(V_{\mathrm {R}}\)\(V_{\mathrm {T}}\)
Adecreasesincreases
Bincreasesdecreases
Cstays the samedecreases
Dstays the sameincreases
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 469, 107, 486]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 789, 486]]<|/det|> The circuit diagram shows a power supply connected to some circuit components. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 665, 516]]<|/det|> In the diagram, P and Q are the terminals of the d.c. power supply. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 527, 660, 672]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 686, 770, 702]]<|/det|> Under which circumstances does the ammeter show a reading other than zero? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 400, 730]]<|/det|> **A** when P is positive or negative <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 504, 756]]<|/det|> **B** the ammeter always shows a zero reading <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 767, 351, 783]]<|/det|> **C** only when P is negative <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 344, 809]]<|/det|> **D** only when P is positive

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 664, 90]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a digital circuit with two inputs and one output. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 100, 780, 276]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 288, 450, 305]]<|/det|> What describes the action of the circuit? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 144, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 317, 195, 335]]<|/det|> AND <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 317, 400, 335]]<|/det|> B NAND <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 317, 531, 335]]<|/det|> C NOR <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 317, 685, 335]]<|/det|> D OR <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 363, 107, 381]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 363, 920, 395]]<|/det|> Either a fuse or a circuit-breaker can be used to protect electrical cables from large currents that could cause overheating. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 405, 715, 547]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 562, 920, 594]]<|/det|> When a fuse is used, where should it be connected, and when a circuit-breaker is used, where should it be connected? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 606, 465, 750]]<|/det|>
position of fuseposition of circuit-breaker
AXX
BXY
CYX
DYY

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 458, 90]]<|/det|>
There is a current of 3.0A in a conductor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 581, 120]]<|/det|>
The current is changed to 6.0A in the opposite direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 134, 712, 150]]<|/det|>
Which effect does this have on the magnetic field around the conductor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 551, 180]]<|/det|>
A It decreases and it acts in the opposite direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 190, 527, 205]]<|/det|>
B It decreases and it acts in the same direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 216, 544, 231]]<|/det|>
C It increases and it acts in the opposite direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 520, 257]]<|/det|>
D It increases and it acts in the same direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 286, 107, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 919, 317]]<|/det|>
A wire is placed in a strong magnetic field. When a current is passed through the wire it moves upwards, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 327, 610, 570]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 583, 315, 599]]<|/det|>
The current is reversed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 613, 440, 629]]<|/det|>
In which direction does the wire move?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 642, 252, 657]]<|/det|>
A downwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 669, 341, 684]]<|/det|>
B towards the north pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 695, 343, 710]]<|/det|>
C towards the south pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 721, 228, 736]]<|/det|>
D upwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 598, 90]]<|/det|> Which diagram represents the structure of a neutral atom? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 100, 850, 225]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 255, 107, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 881, 272]]<|/det|> When a uranium-235 nucleus absorbs a neutron, it becomes unstable and undergoes fission. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 285, 871, 302]]<|/det|> The fission process produces a barium (Ba) nucleus, a krypton (Kr) nucleus and 3 neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 315, 662, 332]]<|/det|> The fission process is represented by the nuclear equation shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[340, 345, 656, 368]]<|/det|> \[_{0}^{1}\mathrm{n} + \mathrm{\ ^{235}_{92}U}\rightarrow \mathrm{\ ^{144}_{56}Ba} + \mathrm{\ ^{...}Kr} + \mathrm{\ ^{3}_{0}^{1}n}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 383, 579, 400]]<|/det|> Which symbol represents the resulting krypton nucleus? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 143, 431]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 695, 431]]<|/det|> 8936Kr B 9134Kr C 9136Kr D 9136Kr <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 460, 107, 479]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 745, 478]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the paths of three different types of radiation X, Y and Z. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 488, 715, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 647, 463, 663]]<|/det|> Which row correctly identifies X, Y and Z? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 573, 804]]<|/det|>
XYZ
Aα-particlesβ-particlesγ-rays
Bβ-particlesα-particlesγ-rays
Cβ-particlesγ-raysα-particles
Dγ-raysα-particlesβ-particles

time
/weeks		count rate
/counts per minute
0100
280
465
654
845
1039
1234
